item.title: Life Insurance
item.dc:creator: gods1son
item.content:encoded:
Life insurance is a contract between an insurer and insured, the insured pays premium to the insurer and the insurer pays the face amount to the beneficiaries of the insured on the death of the insured (in as much as the policy was in force before the death of the insured.) The terminologies that pertains to life insurance:
  • Death benefit: is the amount on a life insurance policy that is payable to the beneficiary when the insured passes away. The death benefit could be paid as a lump-sum to the beneficiary or it can be used to purchase annuities and paid in bits to the beneficiary.
  • Beneficiary: this is the named individual that receives the death benefit when the insured passes away. There are two types of beneficiary which are primary and contingent beneficiary. The former is the first in line to receive the death benefit while the latter receives the benefit if the primary beneficiary has passed away.
  • Life insured: this is the person whose life the policy is purchased on, the death benefit is paid on the death of this individual.
  • Policyholder: entity that owns an insurance policy and has the right to exercise all privileges under the contract of insurance, except where restricted by the rights of an assignee. A policyholder may or may not be the insured.
  • Cash Surrender Value (CSV): the amount available in cash upon voluntary termination of a policy by its owner before it becomes payable by death or maturity. The amount is the cash value stated in the policy minus a surrender charge and any outstanding loans and any interest thereon.
  • Evidence of insurability: a statement or proof of your health, finances or job, which helps the insurer decide if you are an acceptable risk for life insurance.
  • Life Expectancy: the probability of an individual living to a certain age according to a particular mortality table. This is the beginning point in calculating  the basic premium.
  • Policy: the printed legal document stating the terms of insurance contract that is issued to the policyowner by the company.
  • Premium: the payment, or one of the periodic payments, a policyowner agrees to make for an insurance policy. Depending on the terms of the policy, the premium may be paid in one payment or a series of regular payments.
  • Standard Risk: the classification of a person applying for a life insurance policy who fits the physical, occupational and other standards on which the normal premium rates are based.
  • Substandard Risk: the classification of a person applying for a life insurance policy who does not meet the requirements set for the standard risk. An additional premium is charged on substandard risks to provide for the probability that such a person will have a shorter life span than a standard risk.
There are different types of life insurance policies which are :
  • Term Insurance
  • Permanent insurance
    • Whole life insurance
    • Universal life insurance
    • Term to 100 insurance

item.title: Term Life Insurance
item.dc:creator: gods1son
item.content:encoded:
Term insurance is the most traditional life insurance policy wherein the insured gets death benefit if any contingency happens within the policy term. The insured is, however, not entitled to receive any survival benefit if he outlives the policy term. Term insurance provides protection for a specified period of time. This period could be as short as one year or provide coverage for a specific number of years such as 5, 10, 20 years or to a specified age such as 80 or in some cases up to the oldest age in the life insurance mortality tables. Policies are sold with various premium guarantees. The longer the guarantee, the higher the initial premium. If you die during the term period, the company will pay the face amount of the policy to your beneficiary. If you live beyond the term period you had selected, no benefit is payable. As a rule, term policies offer a death benefit with no savings element or cash value. The premiums you pay for term insurance are lower at the earlier ages as compared with the premiums you pay for permanent insurance, but term rates rise as you grow older. Term plans may be "convertible" to a permanent plan of insurance. The coverage can be "level" providing the same benefit until the policy expires or you can have "decreasing" coverage during the term period with the premiums remaining the same. If you do not pay the premium for your term insurance policy, it will generally lapse without cash value, as compared to a permanent type of policy that has a cash value component.

Types of Term Insurance:

  • Renewable Term: this type gives you the right to renew the policy at the end of the term without having to show proof of insurability. However, the premium would be increased. It is a great opportunity not having to prove insurability at the end of the term because your health situation might have deteriorated such that would cause you to be uninsurable. This type ensures that you are able to renew your policy no matter the state of your health.
  • Convertible Term: this type gives you the ability to convert your term insurance policy to a permanent insurance policy. However, you have to exercise this option during the conversion period. If the conversion is done during this period, you do no have to provide information about your health. The premium paid after conversion is based on the current age at conversion.
  • Level or Decreasing Term: With a level term policy, the face amount is the same throughout the period of the policy. With a decreasing term policy, the face amount reduces over the period of the policy. A typical use of decreasing term is for mortgage protection with the face amount decreasing as the mortgage decreases. If the life insured passes away, the face amount is used to pay off the mortgage.
Different forms of terms insurance are annually renewable term, 5-year renewable term, 10-year term, 15-year term, 20-year term, 25-year term, 30-year term, term to a specified age (usually 65).

item.title: Permanent Life Insurance
item.dc:creator: gods1son
item.content:encoded:
Permanent life insurance is a type of insurance that provides coverage for the entire lifetime of the insured, as long as the premiums are paid.

Features of permanent life policies

  1. Level premiums: The premiums for the permanent life insurance remains the same for the entire life of the insured (except for universal life insurance where the insured has the flexibility of changing the premium). Even though the risk of death rises with age, it has no impact on the premiums, this is because the premiums in the early years are higher than the risk represented by the insured. The "extra" premium (compared to the risk) paid in the early years serves as a policy reserves which helps to annul the premium paid in later years when the insured is at a higher risk.
  2. Cash values: also called CSV (cash surrender value), these are reserves accumulated as a result of premium payments. The cash value is available to the policy owner to borrow from or the money will be given to the policy owner if he/she decides to cancel (surrender) the policy.
  3. Non-forfeiture options: When a policyholder  discontinues payments of premium on a policy, the CSV gives the policyholder some extra protection called the non-forfeiture options which are in the three forms:
    • Automatic premium loan: The CSV is used to pay premiums for the period of time until the CSV is exhausted, this provides some breathing space for the policyholder and he/she can resume payment after the CSV is used up or the policy will be terminated after the grace period (30 days after the due date for payment of premium).
    • Reduced paid-up permanent policy: The CSV is used to purchase a permanent insurance with a reduced death benefit and no further premiums will be required.
    • Extended term insurance: The CSV is used to purchase a term insurance with the same death benefit but the years of coverage depends on the amount of CSV available, no further premiums would be required.
  4. Participating policies and policy “dividends”: a participating policy is such that shares in the profits made by the insurance company's investments. The profits is not guaranteed but if the company makes some profits (with other considerations), dividends are paid to the participating policy holders which they can use to pay the premiums or used to purchase additional protection or left to accumulate more.
  5. Non-participating policies: A non-participating policy does not receive from the insurer's profit (even if available).
  6. Death Benefits: this is also called the Face Amount, this is the amount of money that goes to the beneficiary of the policy owner when the life insured passes on.

Types of Permanent Life Insurance

There are different variations of the permanent life insurance which are:

  • Whole Life Insurance
  • Universal Life Insurance
  • Term to 100
  • Variable Life Insurance
  • Variable Universal Life Insurance

The first three are the most popular types of permanent life insurance. They are discussed in the drop-down menu above.

item.title: Homepage
item.dc:creator: gods1son
item.content:encoded:
Insurance is no longer a new topic, as we all have some form of insurance coverage. Auto insurance being the commonest of the various types of insurance coverage that exists. Others include life insurance, home insurance, disability insurance, critical illness insurance and so on. However, not everyone really understands what insurance entails, the terminologies used in the insurance industry. This site would educate readers on life insurance and the general terms used in this industry to a reasonable extent. Insurance is a contract between an insurance company(also called insurer) and the insured. The insured pays a certain amount of money called "premium" to the insurer, while in return, the insurer provides guarantee of compensation for loss, death, injury, damage as specified in the agreement. Insurance helps individuals, businesses to protect themselves against "huge" potential losses at a reasonable rate (premium). The potential loss has to be reasonably "huge" because it will not be reasonable to pay premiums to protect yourself against $100 loss. The purpose of insurance is to manage risk by sharing the risk with the insurer. Reasons to purchase insurance coverage includes the following:
  1. Protecting family after one's death from loss of income
  2. Provide money for debt repayment on death
  3. Protecting against a key employee (provides money to hire and train another person)
  4. Buying out a partner or co-shareholder after his or her death
  5. Protecting your home against hazards such as fire, flooding etc
  6. Protecting yourself against lawsuits
  7. Protecting yourself in the event of disability
  8. Protecting your car against theft or losses incurred because of accidents
  9. Providing cash for dependencies in the case of death or disability
  10. and many more
There are various kinds of insurance coverage, examples includes the following:
  • Life insurance (main subject of this site)
  • Auto insurance
  • Home insurance
  • Pet insurance
  • Key person insurance
  • Disability insurance
  • Travel insurance
  • Business overhead insurance

item.title: Whole Life Insurance
item.dc:creator: gods1son
item.content:encoded:
The Whole Life Insurance is the most common type of permanent life. The whole life policy premiums and death benefits remain fixed for the duration of the policy. There is usually a guaranteed minimum rate of return, which means that there is a minimum amount of interest guaranteed to the CSV. Some whole life policy are participating, which means that the insurer pays out dividend to the policy owner. The initial premium calculation is based on some factors which include age, sex, smoking habits, health status among others.

The graph on the left explains why the premium remains level for the duration of the coverage. At the early stage of the policy, the insurer usually charges a premium which is greater than the cost of insurance (more premium than the risk).

As the life insured gets older, there is higher risk of death but the premium remains the same as it was when the life insured was younger. The higher premium charged at the earlier years of the policy is used to offset the premium at the older age.

If you had paid the high premium at the early age of the policy and you decide to cancel the policy when you are older, the insurer will refund a certain percentage of the reserve accumulated. The refund of the reserve is called the Cash Surrender Value.

Some of the whole life insurance out there are:

  • BMO Guaranteed-Life Plus
  • CAA Guaranteed Issue Life Insurance
  • ScotiaLife Guaranteed Life Insurance
  • StateFarm Guaranteed Whole Life Insurance

item.title: Universal Life Insurance
item.dc:creator: gods1son
item.content:encoded:
To start with, the very distinct characteristics of the Universal Life Insurance is the flexibility. The ULife policy consists of two types: the first one is the insurance account and the other side is the investment account. The two types of accounts are flexible, the policyholder can decide to increase or decrease both premiums and death benefits (within limits set by insurer).

The additional money paid above the premiums goes into the investment account, the policy owner can choose how the money should be invested and the securities to be purchased. The rate of return is however not guaranteed. The image below shows how the premiums of the universal life policy is divided into the two account types.

item.title: Term to 100
item.dc:creator: gods1son
item.content:encoded:
Term to 100 is also a permanent life insurance which provides coverage till age 100. This is cheaper in premiums compared to the other permanent life insurance. The premiums is leveled throughout the duration of the policy, however there is no cash surrender value in the Term to 100 insurance. Term to 100 is commonly used if you are looking for low cost insurance for the rest of your life for such needs as creating an estate or burial expenses.

Some Term to 100 Insurance out there:

  • BMO Pure Term 100
  • RBC Term 100 insurance
  • ScotiaLife Term to 100
  • StateFarm Term to 100
  • CAA Term Life Insurance
